projectDesc.p: To the tune “Still Wind and Waves”—"Since the Spring Came" is part of The Global Medieval Sourcebook, a digital compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. This larger project comprises computer-readable transcriptions and/or editions of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century, and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia; accompanied by new English translations; high-resolution digital images of manuscript/early print sources, where available; an apparatus that includes critical introductions, textual notes and annotations; and a flexible user interface with which to navigate these materials.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.rdg: To the tune “Still Wind and Waves”—"Since the Spring Came"
Since the spring came,
I am saddened by the green and worried by the red.
My girlish heart cares about nothing.
The sun ascends the flowery branch,
The orioles fly through the willow twigs;
I am still lying under the fragrant quilt.
My warm and soft skin wastes away;
My shiny cloud-like hair droops down.
Listless all day, I am tired of putting on makeup.
What can I do?
I resent that ever since the fickle one left,
There is not a single message from him.
If only I knew (it would be like this).
I regret back then,
That I did not lock away his carved saddle,
I should have made him face the chicken window,
Giving him only colorful paper and an ivory brush,
Restraining him and asking him to chant and recite.
I should have been with him all day,
Not letting him avoid me.
With needles and threads, sitting beside him.
Promise me
That we won’t let our youth
Pass away in vain.
